Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


> I'd like to extract a bunch of 'characteristics' from each image, and
use 
>those as inputs into a neural network, and use that data as the
training 
>data. Then, when I add a bunch of new pictures to the database, I can
let 
>the network pre-classify their relationship to the others. If the
network 
>doesn't have a CLEAR preference, it passes on the comparison. When it
is 
>done, the best pictures automatically end up near the top, the dogs 
>automatically fall to the bottom. 


I've thinking about how to do exactly that ( with the intention of
processing motion picture data for a vision system ) and combining it
with ideas from the emergent behaviour theory. If you develop a set of
networks, one for each 'charachteristic' your looking for, and all work
in parrellel from the same input. They become the 'input layer of
networks' and then you can evolve a network who's input is from that
input layer to actually judge the quality/fitness of the image, from
those charachteristics.
I havn't actually tried this approach yet, myself, but I'm working
toward it. The "real job" has been too much fun. If you go for this
approach, there will be some decisions you have to make about how to
decide if charachteristics exists or not, and I would really like to see
how you choose to filter for them. It could be as simple as having a
list of pictures, with corrosponding values for magnitude of
charachteristic. A sticky point is things like curves vs lines. Do you
have two different networks, one to detect curves, the other lines? Or
can one network decide that there are more lines than curves, and make a
decision....
Quick question: what do you think your input resolution will be?

chad 

------=_NextPart_000_02AC_01C44F0B.699BF6C0

<HTML>
<BODY>
 <br>
> I'd like to extract a bunch of 'characteristics' from each image, and use  <br>
>those as inputs into a neural network, and use that data as the training  <br>
>data.  Then, when I add a bunch of new pictures to the database, I can let  <br>
>the network pre-classify their relationship to the others.  If the network  <br>
>doesn't have a CLEAR preference, it passes on the comparison.  When it is  <br>
>done, the best pictures automatically end up near the top, the dogs  <br>
>automatically fall to the bottom. <br>
 <br>
 <br>
I've thinking about how to do exactly that ( with the intention of processing motion picture data for a vision system ) and combining it with ideas from the emergent behaviour theory. If you develop a set of networks, one for each 'charachteristic' your looking for, and all work in parrellel from the same input. They become the 'input layer of networks' and then you can evolve a network who's input is from that input layer to actually judge the quality/fitness of the image, from those charachteristics.<br>
I havn't actually tried this approach yet, myself, but I'm working toward it. The "real job" has been too much fun. If you go for this approach, there will be some decisions you have to make about how to decide if charachteristics exists or not, and I would really like to see how you choose to filter for them. It could be as simple as having a list of pictures, with corrosponding values for magnitude of charachteristic. A sticky point is things like curves vs lines. Do you have two different networks, one to detect curves, the other lines? Or can one network decide that there are more lines than curves, and make a decision....<br>
Quick question: what do you think your input resolution will be?<br>
<br>
chad
</BODY></HTML>
